title: Hard-Fi
text:
{{Short description|English indie rock band}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Hard-Fi | image = Hard-Fi Hurrciane-Festival.jpg | caption = Hard-Fi at the 2006 [[Hurricane Festival]] in [[Scheeßel]], Germany | landscape = yes | background = group_or_band | alias = | origin = [[Staines-upon-Thames]], [[Surrey]], England | genre = [[Indie rock]], [[alternative rock]] | years_active = 2003–2014, 2022—present | label = {{hlist|[[Necessary Records|Necessary]]|[[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]}} | associated_acts = [[Contempo (band)|Contempo]] | website = | current_members = [[Richard Archer]]
[[Steve Kemp (musician)|Steve Kemp]]
Kai Stephens
Ross Phillips }} '''Hard-Fi''' are an English [[indie rock]] band, formed in 2003 in [[Staines-upon-Thames]], [[Surrey]]. The band's most recent lineup before going on hiatus consisted of [[Richard Archer]] ([[singing|lead vocals]] and [[electric guitar|guitar]]), Kai Stephens ([[bass guitar]] and backing vocals) and [[Steve Kemp (musician)|Steve Kemp]] ([[drum kit|drums]] and backing vocals). Founding member Ross Phillips (guitar and backing vocals) left the band on 6 May 2013 but returned in 2014 to promote the release of their greatest hits album, ''[[Hard-Fi: Best of 2004 – 2014|Best of 2004 – 2014]]'', and the one-off gig on 13 February 2014. They achieved chart success with their third single, "[[Hard to Beat]]"[http://acharts.us/song/2143 "Music Charts: "Hard-Fi - Hard to Beat"]. aCharts.us. and then followed by other successful singles such as "[[Living for the Weekend (Hard-Fi song)|Living for the Weekend]]"[http://acharts.us/song/9869 "Music Charts: "Hard-Fi - Living for the Weekend"]. aCharts.us. and "[[Cash Machine]]",[http://acharts.us/song/7280 "Music Charts: "Hard-Fi - Cash Machine"]. aCharts.us. which all reached the top 20 of the [[UK Singles Chart]].[http://acharts.us/performer/hardfi "Music Charts: "Hard-Fi"]. aCharts.us. Their debut album ''[[Stars of CCTV]]'' was released on 4 July 2005,{{Cite web|url=http://www.hard-fi.com/discography.php|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071223214846/http://www.hard-fi.com/discography.php|url-status=dead|title=Hard-Fi : Discography|archivedate=23 December 2007}} and although receiving critical acclaim (''[[NME]]'' called it the 23rd best album of 2005 and it was nominated for the [[Mercury Prize]] and two [[Brit Awards]]; Best British Group and Best British Rock Act),{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/bestalbumsandtracksoftheyear/2005-2-1045347|title=2005 - NME|date=2016-10-10|work=NME|access-date=2017-09-11|language=en-US}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4207346.stm|title=Hard-Fi battle to beat Mercury odds|publisher=BBC | date=4 September 2005 | access-date=5 January 2010|first=Ian|last=Youngs}} it did not reach No. 1 on the UK Albums Chart until six months later on 22 January 2006.[http://acharts.us/album/16904 "Music Charts: "Hard-Fi - Stars of CCTV"]. aCharts.us. It originally entered the charts at number 6. The band's second album ''[[Once Upon a Time in the West (album)|Once Upon a Time in the West]]'' was released on 3 September 2007 and reached number 1 in its first week.[http://acharts.us/album/27862 "Music Charts: "Hard-Fi - Once Upon a Time in the West"]. aCharts.us. Their third album ''[[Killer Sounds]]'', which features the singles "[[Good for Nothing (song)|Good for Nothing]]", "[[Fire in the House]]" and "[[Bring It On (Hard-Fi song)|Bring It On]]", was released on 19 August 2011 and debuted at number 9 on the UK Albums Chart. == History == === Contempo band === [[Richard Archer]] decided to return to his hometown of [[Staines]], crushed by the lack of success of his former band [[Contempo (band)|Contempo]] and the death of his father from cancer. He said "I moved back to Staines because I ran out of money and it was quite a shock." Archer claims that music business insiders tried to dissuade the band's manager Warren Clarke from managing him. When Archer asked his publishers for some money to record the new songs that he had written, they terminated his contract instead. "People told him, don't bother with Archer, he's damaged goods, you're wasting your time."{{cite web|url=http://www.hard-fi.com/flash.html|title=Hard-Fi flash|publisher=Hard-Fi|format=Flash|access-date=19 September 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006141444/http://www.hard-fi.com/flash.html|archive-date=6 October 2007|url-status=dead}}{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wvAspgJdhlA |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/wvAspgJdhlA |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=Hard-Fi - Rockin' The City Video Podcast Part One|publisher=Hard-Fi}}{{cbignore}} === Formation and early success === While Archer was making demos to produce an album, he went into the Staines hi-fi shop where Ross Phillips worked, simply so he could listen to his latest demos on the shop's best equipment. Philips apparently asked Archer who had played guitar on his demos and Archer said that it was himself. Phillips said it was "shit"{{cite web |url=http://www.leftlion.co.uk/articles.cfm/id/652 |title=Hard-Fi Interview - Nottingham Articles |publisher=LeftLion.co.uk |date=27 April 2005 |access-date=2011-08-17}} and was therefore recruited to play guitar for the new group. [[Steve Kemp (musician)|Steve Kemp]] was already an old friend of Archer, while it took Kai Stephens little persuasion to leave his job as a "pest killer" at [[Rentokil Initial|Rentokil]]. When Stephens played guitar before joining Hard-Fi, he liked to copy chords from bands such as [[Led Zeppelin]] and [[Pink Floyd]] who are two of his favourite artists along with [[The Clash]] and hip-hop acts such as [[Run DMC]] and [[N.W.A]].{{cite news |url=http://www.fender.co.uk/news/index.php?display_article=104 |first=Nigel |last=Trimmington |title=A Pint & A Chat With ... Hard Fi |work=Fender News |publisher=Fender.co.uk |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060628164026/http://www.fender.co.uk/news/index.php?display_article=104 |archive-date=28 June 2006 |df=dmy-all }} The band were signed to newly formed independent label [[Necessary Records]], owned by Clarke. The majority of ''Stars of CCTV'' was recorded in a variety of unusual acoustic environments - in bedrooms, in pubs, and played back in their producer, Wolsey White's, [[BMW]]. 1000 copies of this record were pressed with only 500 going on public sale, and the initial plan was to sell 1000 each time. However, it quickly sold out, receiving critical acclaim and radio play, proving a lot more successful than the band had imagined. Most of the album was recorded in a disused [[Taxicab|mini cab]] office, which cost them about £300 and is known to this day as the "Cherry Lips" Studio. The band used to try to make their music sound more atmospheric by putting a microphone in the corridor to add echo; listening closely to the record reveals that this also picked up passers-by humming and whistling and the occasional aeroplane flying overhead. Archer desperately tried to generate publicity for the band through the ''Staines Observer'', to no avail; "We sent them a press release and a photo," said Archer. "The press release was all like, the hard-hitting sound of the streets and stuff. And the article came out going, 'Richard Archer, former pupil of Thamesmead School ...' Whatever you say, they seem to be most interested in what school you went to." The band were then licensed to the major label [[Atlantic Records]] in December 2004, where they were given the chance to re-record the album in the renowned [[Abbey Road Studios]], among other well known studios, however they went back to the cab office to maintain their sound. === ''Stars of CCTV'' === {{Main|Stars of CCTV}} The band were one of the acts opening for [[Green Day]], alongside [[Taking Back Sunday]] and [[Jimmy Eat World]] on their two-day residency of the [[Milton Keynes Bowl]] in June 2005. [[Simple Plan]] were initially booked though cancelled only a few weeks before the show, and Hard-Fi were made as a last minute booking and opened on both days. Their debut album's launch party was scheduled to be 7 July 2005 at Cheekees nightclub in Staines, however this was cancelled due to the ill health of Richard's mother, and the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|London bombings]] also occurring that day. Her death resulted in the band pulling out of the [[Glastonbury festival]]. The launch party was rescheduled for 13 July 2005 and the venue changed to [[Ladbroke Grove]], London. The ''Stars of CCTV'' album re-entered the official UK album chart at No. 4 on 1 January 2006. Two places higher than it originally went in on the week of its release, the album climbed from No. 33. ''Stars of CCTV'' finally got to No. 1 on 22 January. The band's re-release of "Cash Machine" entered the official Top 40 singles chart at No. 14 on 1 January. The album has reached sales of 1.2 million copies worldwide{{cite news|author=Alexis Petridis |url=http://music.guardian.co.uk/reviews/story/0,,2159245,00.html |title=Hard-Fi, Once Upon a Time in the West |publisher=Music.guardian.co.uk |date= 31 August 2007|access-date=2011-08-17 |location=London}} and sales of over 600,000 in the UK alone. Hard-Fi gained increased prominence in the UK when ''Stars of CCTV'' was nominated for the 2005 [[Mercury Music Prize]].{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/music/4207346.stm | work=BBC News | title=Hard-Fi battle to beat Mercury odds | date=4 September 2005 | access-date=4 May 2010 | first=Ian | last=Youngs}} ''Stars of CCTV'' scored 74 out of 100 on Metacritic.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/hardfi/starsofcctv?q=hard-fi |title=Stars of CCTV Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More at Metacritic |publisher=Metacritic.com |access-date=2011-08-17}} In February 2006, the band were nominated for two [[BRIT Awards]], Best British Group and Best British Rock Act, alongside international superstars such as [[Gorillaz]], [[Franz Ferdinand (band)|Franz Ferdinand]] and [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]]. Richard spoke about the nominations, "I don't think we'll win it, especially best group when you've got [[Coldplay]], Franz Ferdinand and Gorillaz in there, they're kind of big hitters, but you never know, [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton]] drew with [[Manchester United F.C.|Man United]]". "Last week I would have probably said 'nah it's all rubbish', but now I'm nominated it's great but what is good is that there's a real wide spread of stuff there, but there's no Best Dance award and the urban category is more pop than what's quality."{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ny9ubamcv98 |title=LEE RYAN & HARD FI - INTERVIEW(CDUK - 14.01.06) |publisher=YouTube |access-date=2011-08-17}}{{cbignore}}{{Dead Youtube links|date=February 2022}} === ''Once Upon a Time in the West'' === {{Main|Once Upon a Time in the West (album)}} Hard-Fi expanded the "Cherry Lips", their taxi cab office which they used to record, making more room for equipment after having searched fruitlessly for a space. Archer described the record as "darker and more expansive". A working title for the Album was "Bat out of Staines".{{cite web|author=Neil McCormick |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/rockandjazzmusic/3667093/Hard-Fi-Like-a-bat-out-of-Staines.html |title=Hard-Fi: Like a bat out of Staines |website=Telegraph.co.uk |access-date=2020-04-10}} The first single from the album was "[[Suburban Knights]]", released on 20 August. The single had its first play on 18 June 2007, at 7:20 pm (BST) on Radio 1. The album ''[[Once Upon a Time in the West (album)|Once Upon a Time in the West]]'' was released on 3 September 2007 when the band launched it at midnight in [[Virgin Megastore]] in [[Oxford Street]], London with a live performance from a selected set list followed by a CD signing.{{cite web|url=http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=18|title=The Wild West Comes To Virgin|publisher=Hard-Fi HQ|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112212428/http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=18|archive-date=12 November 2007}} The following day, the band performed at [[Maida Vale#BBC Studios|Maida Vale Studios]] to a small audience who earned their tickets through Radio 1.{{cite web|url=http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=20|title=WIN TICKETS TO INTIMATE RADIO 1 SHOW|publisher=Hard-Fi HQ|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112212756/http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=20|archive-date=12 November 2007}}{{cite web|url=http://www.acedmagazine.com/steve_hardfi.html|title=Steve Kemp interview|publisher=Aced Magazine|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071002221255/http://acedmagazine.com/steve_hardfi.html|archive-date=2 October 2007}} The album cover of ''Once Upon a Time in the West'' has an orange background with the album title at the top, and "NO COVER ART." written in large, white letters below. The artwork has received criticism, however, top cover art designer [[Peter Saville (artist)|Peter Saville]] has described it as "a 'White Album' for the digital culture."{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/music/features/H/hardfitimeline.html|title=Hard-Fi Timeline|publisher=Channel 4}}{{cite web|url=http://www.2-4-7-music.com/searches/newsitem.asp?ArtistName=Hard-Fi&FeatureType=NEWS|archive-url=https://archive.today/20060525101330/http://www.2-4-7-music.com/searches/newsitem.asp?ArtistName=Hard-Fi&FeatureType=NEWS|url-status=dead|archive-date=2006-05-25|title=Hard-Fi News|publisher=Crud Magazine}} On 9 September 2007, ''Once Upon a Time in the West'' went straight in at No. 1 on the UK Albums Chart, giving Hard-Fi a second No. 1 album.{{cite web |url=http://ukforums.infopop.cc/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/751106815/m/77410860201 |title=Listen to Once Upon a Time in the West on MYSPACE - Topic Powered by eve community |publisher=Ukforums.infopop.cc |access-date=2011-08-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110816152505/http://ukforums.infopop.cc/eve/forums/a/tpc/f/751106815/m/77410860201 |archive-date=16 August 2011}} It received positive reviews including five stars from ''[[The Observer]] Monthly''Observer Music Monthly 24 and four stars from [[Q Magazine|''Q'' Magazine]],{{cite web |url=http://www.qthemusic.com |title=Q Magazine | Music news & reviews, music videos, band pictures & interviews |publisher=Qthemusic.com |access-date=2011-08-17 |archive-date=10 August 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200810004354/https://www.qthemusic.com/ |url-status=dead }} scoring 70 out of 100 on Metacritic.{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/music/artists/hardfi/onceuponatimeinthewest?q=hard-fi |title=Once Upon A Time in the West Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More at Metacritic |publisher=Metacritic.com |access-date=2011-08-17}} The album was more popular than their debut album ''Stars of CCTV'' in other countries, as it reached Japan's Top 10 chart. Mexico, Argentina, Brazil and Central America began to show interest in the band as the first single from the album, "Suburban Knights", charted in all of their respective charts, reaching No. 5 in Peru, No. 3 in Guatemala, No. 2 El Salvador, No. 8 Mexico alongside their second single "[[Can't Get Along (Without You)]]" which spent two weeks on No. 1 in Peru and Argentina. On 10 March 2008, the third single, "[[I Shall Overcome]]" was released in the UK, where it reached No. 35, whilst making the top five in South America just like the previous two singles entering in at No. 4.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WIoBCgrFRew |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/WIoBCgrFRew |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=NME Video: Hard-Fi at Koko |publisher=Youtube.com |date=12 February 2008 |access-date=2011-08-17}}{{cbignore}} === ''Killer Sounds'' === {{Main|Killer Sounds}} During the 2008 [[Christmas and holiday season|Christmas period]], Hard-Fi released a Christmas message to their fans announcing that they would be back in the new year with "a wicked new album".{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xGg5cmncRcQ |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/xGg5cmncRcQ |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=HARD-FI: Rockin The city "CHRISTMAS MESSAGE" |publisher=Youtube.com |date=15 December 2008 |access-date=2011-08-17}}{{cbignore}} On 2 February 2009, Phillips released a blog on the band's official [[Myspace]] page, saying "me and the boys are now back in the cherry lips recording facility working hard on the new tunes. Sounding great by the way. We're really pleased with how the album's shaping up. Hopefully over the next few months we'll put some bits and pieces up for you to have a listen."{{cite web |url=http://blogs.myspace.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=blog.view&friendID=18327016&blogID=468110726 |title=MySpace.com Blogs - ROSS BLOGS - HARD-FI MySpace Blog |publisher=Blogs.myspace.com |date=2 February 2009 |access-date=2011-08-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/66i6ekTVr?url=http://www.myspace.com/hardfi/blog/468110726 |archive-date=6 April 2012}} On 29 October 2010, Hard-Fi made a blog posting on their website stating that they were starting production on their new album.{{Cite web|url=http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=91|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100522093228/http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=91|url-status=dead|title=Steve's Blog: "Scary Monsters and Super Freaks"|archivedate=22 May 2010}} On 14 February 2011, Archer posted an update on the band's [[Facebook]] page, which revealed that six of the eleven album tracks had been mixed. Producers that worked with Hard-Fi on their third album include [[Stuart Price]] and [[Greg Kurstin]]. On 7 March, Hard-Fi confirmed that they are getting closer to completing the album. Archer posted a status on Facebook, saying "going back into the studio to mix the final tracks for the album, we've got two weeks booked to finish off and tweak a few bits and pieces from the last batch. Thinking about photos, a video, artwork and getting out and doing a few gigs - sooner than you might think." On 28 April, Hard-Fi's latest single "[[Good for Nothing (song)|Good for Nothing]]" was premiered on [[Zane Lowe]]'s [[BBC Radio 1|Radio 1]] show receiving airplay as the 'Hottest Record in the World'. In an accompanying Archer announced that the album is called ''[[Killer Sounds]]''.{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/news/hard-fi/56816 |title=Hard-Fi announce first London show for over three years |work=Nme|date=23 May 2011 |access-date=2011-08-17}} On 7 May, "Good for Nothing" was featured on ''[[Soccer AM]]'''s [[Premier League]] goals portion of the show. The single was then made available to listen to on Hard-Fi's official [[YouTube]] channel.{{cite web|title=Hard-Fi - Good For Nothing |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ZVe96l_h-SM |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/ZVe96l_h-SM |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|publisher=YouTube}}{{cbignore}} Having been made available for listening on Hard-Fi's website since 22 May, "Good for Nothing" was finally released on 17 June and debuted on the UK Singles Chart at number No. 10 and on the UK Rock Chart at No. 2. The second single to be released from the album was "[[Fire in the House]]" on 7 August 2011. Despite suggestions that it would struggle due to strong competition from contestants competing on [[The X Factor (British series 8)|the eighth series of ''The X Factor'']], which was ongoing at the time,{{cite web|url=https://www.digitalspy.com/music/a334082/hard-fi-new-album-feels-like-starting-again/|title=Hard-Fi: 'New album feels like starting again'|publisher=Digital Spy|first=Tom|last=Eames|date=9 August 2011|accessdate=16 June 2021}} ''Killer Sounds'' was officially released in the UK, Ireland and other European territories on 22 August and entered the UK Albums Chart at No. 9. "[[Bring It On (Hard-Fi song)|Bring It On]]", the third and final single, was released on 24 October 2011. Following unspecified legal difficulties, the album's USA & Canada release date was delayed until 15 March 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/hardfi/posts/174936002654992 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/15539010626/174936002654992 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=Hard-Fi - KILLER SOUNDS (Special edition) NOW AVAILABLE IN... |website=Facebook.com |date=2017-12-14 |access-date=2020-04-10}}{{cbignore}} === Greatest hits album and hiatus === In March 2012, Archer told [[Gigwise]] that Hard-Fi are hoping to release their next album in a shorter interval than the four years between ''Once Upon a Time in the West'' and ''Killer Sounds'', although no estimated release date was set.{{cite web|url=http://www.gigwise.com/news/71820/hard-fi-promises-no-long-wait-for-new-album |title=Hard-Fi promises 'no long wait' for new album |website=Gigwise.com |date=2020-03-19 |access-date=2020-04-10}} The band released some samples of studio material from their upcoming album via their official Facebook page in March 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/hardfi/posts/128408450676313 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/15539010626/128408450676313 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=Hard-Fi - Happy Friday Everyone! A little teaser/trailer... |website=Facebook.com |date=2013-03-22 |access-date=2020-04-10}}{{cbignore}} On 6 May 2013, the band announced via their Facebook page that Phillips was leaving the band to concentrate on 'different things'.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/hardfi/posts/10152787185270627 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/facebook/15539010626/10152787185270627 |archive-date=2022-02-26 |url-access=limited|title=Hard-Fi - Some news... It's with great regret we have to... |website=Facebook.com |date=2013-05-06 |access-date=2020-04-10}}{{cbignore}} On 27 November 2013, it was announced that Hard-Fi would be releasing a greatest hits compilation album called ''[[Hard-Fi: Best of 2004 – 2014]]''. The album was released on 27 January 2014.{{cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/hard-fi/74095|title=Hard-Fi to release greatest hits compilation|date=27 November 2013|work=[[NME]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|access-date=28 November 2013}} They also played a one-off sell out gig at the Bloomsbury Ballroom in London on 13 February 2014 along with Phillips. The band hasn't released any music since and said on [[Twitter]]{{cite tweet|author=Hard-Fi|user=HARD_FI|number=1086271197258514433|date=18 January 2019|title=Hmmm I was under the impression we were still hiatusing - is that a word? Hiatusing?? https://t.co/AfB3SVthF6}} they're on a hiatus when some people believed they had disbanded. ===Reunion=== In January 2022, a photo was posted from the band's official Twitter account from inside a recording studio, possibly hinting toward an end to their nearly 8 year hiatus.{{cite tweet|user=hard_fi|number=1481926468032733185|title=What!?|author=Hard-Fi|access-date=28 January 2022|language=en}} In April 2022, posters were posted in various London underground stations featuring the band's trademark yellow and black camera logo, with the text "London 01.10.22" suggesting the band will be playing their first live show since 2014.{{cite news|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/hard-fi-appear-to-tease-stars-of-cctv-anniversary-show-3204572|title=Hard-Fi appear to tease 'Stars of CCTV' anniversary show|last=Skinner|first=Tom|date=14 April 2022|work=NME}} On 24 April, during a [[Facebook Live]] stream, Archer shared details of the gig, which will take place at London's O2 Forum Kentish Town on 1 October. He confirmed all original members, including Ross Phillips who had previously left the band, would be present.{{cite news|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/hard-fi-announce-special-london-reunion-gig-new-music-3211354|title=Hard-Fi announce special London reunion gig and hint at new music|last=Daly|first=Rhian|date=24 April 2022|work=NME}} == Musical style == Hard-Fi's lyrics are based mostly on working class life, the band themselves coming from a self-sufficient suburban lifestyle in Staines. This is notable in tracks such as "[[Suburban Knights]]" ("Those bills keep dropping through my door") and "[[Living for the Weekend (Hard-Fi song)|Living for the Weekend]]" ("I've been working all week - I'm tired"), while other songs such as "Tonight", despite still being about suburban life, focus more on ambitions. Some songs are also based on social realism, "Feltham is Singing Out" is inspired by [[Zahid Mubarek]]{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2006/may/12/popandrock1 | work=The Guardian | location=London | title=Hard-Fi want to be the world's biggest band. But first they have to open a pub in Staines | first=Alexis | last=Petridis | date=12 May 2006 | access-date=4 May 2010}} who was sent to the [[Feltham Young Offenders' Institution]] and was murdered by his racist cellmate. Other songs, such as "[[Better Do Better]]" and "Move on Now", are centred around the premise of how hard romantic relationships can be. Once Hard-Fi were becoming successful, Richard's mother died and the song "Help Me Please" is about how difficult it was for him having his dreams come true after many unsuccessful bands but realises he has no parents to share the joy with. Similarly, "The King" is about Richard returning to Staines and finding everything completely different, and realising everything of which he knew and loved had disappeared. He describes "Little Angel" as [[Christina Aguilera]] having a fight with [[The Clash]] in a [[Northern Soul]] club.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uhcsj_WYqVY |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/uhcsj_WYqVY |archive-date=2021-12-21 |url-status=live|title=NME TV - Hard-Fi track by track album interview|magazine=[[NME]]}}{{cbignore}} Archer stated that they were heavily influenced by [[soul music|soul]] and [[dance music]].{{cite web|url=https://metro.co.uk/2007/11/16/60-seconds-richard-archer-520890/ |title=60 SECONDS: Richard Archer |publisher=Metro.co.uk |date=16 November 2007 |access-date=2011-08-17}} == Name == "Hard-Fi" is the name given to the sound produced by [[Lee "Scratch" Perry]], a [[reggae]] and [[dub music|dub]] artist, at his [[Black Ark]]{{cite web|url=http://www.blackark.com/ |title=The Black Ark Lee Scratch Perry and the Upsetters Classic Dub Roots and Reggae community |publisher=Blackark.com |access-date=2011-08-17}} [[recording studio]]. Being admirers of Perry's work, the band named themselves after his distinctive sound. Archer said "Since then I've been desperately trying to find the biography where I read it; but I may have dreamt it." == Live == [[File:HARD-Fi, 2006.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Hard-Fi in concert at Sala Caracol in [[Madrid]], Spain, 2006]] Hard-Fi's first live performance was at [[Manchester]]'s "In the City" music event in 2003 before they were signed to a record label.{{cite web|url=http://www.ticketnest.com/concert-tickets/Hard-Fi/index.php |title=Hard Fi Tickets, Cheap Hard Fi Tickets |publisher=Ticket Nest |access-date=2011-08-17}}{{cite web|url = http://www.citylife.co.uk/music/news/4825_hard_fi_to_hit_city|title = Hard-Fi to hit city|access-date = 2010-09-24}} They played London's [[Carling Academy Brixton|Brixton Academy]] from 14 to 18 May, making them one of the few bands to play five consecutive sold-out nights there and the first to do so off the back of their debut album.{{cite magazine |last=Roberts |first=Colin |url=http://www.drownedinsound.com/articles/617105 |title=News - Hard-Fi play five night Brixton Academy jaunt |magazine=Drowned in Sound |date=6 February 2006 |access-date=2011-08-17 |archive-date=25 December 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225175459/http://www.drownedinsound.com/articles/617105 |url-status=dead }} After the success of the ''Stars of CCTV'' album and of hit single "[[Hard to Beat]]", it allowed them to end up in a mini-reunion of [[The Specials]], performing "[[Ghost Town (The Specials song)|Ghost Town]]" with [[Jerry Dammers]] and [[Neville Staples]] at the [[Love Music Hate Racism]] gig.{{cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/hard-fi/23076|title=Hard-Fi team up with very special guest|date=16 May 2006|work=NME|access-date=17 August 2011}} [[Mick Jones (The Clash)|Mick Jones]] of [[The Clash]] is a renowned fan of the band, while [[Paul Weller (singer)|Paul Weller]] came to their rehearsal rooms and jammed a version of "[[Town Called Malice]]", something of which Kaichen Stephens says "gives us bragging rights over all of Staines". All of these artists were quite inspirational towards Hard-Fi while they were recording ''Stars of CCTV'', perhaps The Specials and The Clash being the larger influences. Jones also appeared with them performing "[[E=MC2 (song)|E=MC²]]" by his former band [[Big Audio Dynamite]]. Jones had previously helped produce tracks by Archer's prior band, Contempo who had recorded a cover of "[[London's Burning (The Clash song)|London's Burning]]" by The Clash. Hard-Fi supported [[Green Day]] at their two gigs at [[Milton Keynes Bowl]], performing in front of approximately 65,000 people.{{cite web |author=Virtual Festivals |url=http://www.virtualfestivals.com/artists/gigreviews/2012 |title=Green Day - Milton Keynes Bowl 2005 |publisher=Virtualfestivals.com |date=6 July 2005 |access-date=2011-08-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929125504/http://www.virtualfestivals.com/artists/gigreviews/2012 |archive-date=29 September 2011}} During December 2005, the band played at London's [[London Astoria|Astoria]]. The performance was filmed and released ''[[In Operation]]'' on DVD. The performance features all the tracks on ''Stars of CCTV'' plus "You And Me" and the band's version of "[[Seven Nation Army]]" by [[The White Stripes]]. It also comes with ''CCTVersions'' – a CD featuring dubbed versions of album tracks, produced by guests including [[Roots Manuva]] and DJ Wrongtom.{{cite web|url=http://www.hmv.co.uk/hmvweb/displayProductDetails.do?ctx=12;1;58;-1&sku=501650 |title=albums: In Operation: Bonus Dvd (2006) |publisher=HMV.com |date=15 December 2005 |access-date=2011-08-17}} In February 2006, Hard-Fi played the Hammersmith Palais as part of the ''NME'' Awards shows with regular early touring partners [[Boy Kill Boy]].{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/reviews/hard-fi/7865 |title=Hard-Fi - Hard-Fi/Boy Kill Boy/Duels/Distophia, Hammersmith Palain, London Monday, 13 February |work=Nme|date=24 February 2006 |access-date=2011-08-17}} The band played a series of sold-out, intimate dates later in July 2007 previewing the record.{{cite web |url=http://www.lovemusichateracism.com/news/2007/06/19/lmhr-glasto-show-headliner-revealed-today/ |title=Blog Archive » Hard-Fi Confirmed To Headline Love Music Hate Racism Show at Glastonbury'S Left Field Stage This Weekend |publisher=Love Music Hate Racism |date=23 June 2007 |access-date=2011-08-17 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071112165219/http://www.lovemusichateracism.com/news/2007/06/19/lmhr-glasto-show-headliner-revealed-today/ |archive-date=12 November 2007}} The [[UK Festival Awards]] nominated the event in the category for Most Memorable Moment.{{Cite web |title=UK Festival Awards (2007) :: Glastonbury Festival 2007 |url=http://www.festivalawards.com/index.cfm?section=awards.nominees&method=view&year=2007&eventid=598 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021021312/http://www.festivalawards.com/index.cfm?section=awards.nominees&method=view&year=2007&eventid=598 |archivedate=21 October 2007}} Each concert from the band's December UK Tour was recorded in its entirety on audio CD which could be ordered online through Concert Live or bought at the venue for £20.{{Cite web |title=Concert Live | Live CDs | Hard-Fi | Once Upon a Time in December |url=http://www.concertlive.co.uk/Live%20CDs/Hard-Fi/Once%20Upon%20a%20Time%20in%20December.aspx#productheader |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071205175943/http://www.concertlive.co.uk/Live%20CDs/Hard-Fi/Once%20Upon%20a%20Time%20in%20December.aspx#productheader |archive-date=5 December 2007 |url-status=dead}} The CD was titled [[Once Upon a Time in December]]. It was bundled with the next single "[[I Shall Overcome]]".{{Cite web |title=Hard-Fi : News |url=http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=51 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080223182608/http://www.hard-fi.com/news.php?newsID=51 |archivedate=23 February 2008}} == Discography == {{Main|Hard-Fi discography}} ; Studio albums: *''[[Stars of CCTV]]'' (2005) *''[[Once Upon a Time in the West (album)|Once Upon a Time in the West]]'' (2007) *''[[Killer Sounds]]'' (2011) Hard-Fi have their own [[video podcast]], which is known as ''Hard-Fi: Rockin' the City'', available on their website, [[iTunes]], [[Myspace]] page and [[YouTube]] channel.{{cite web |url=http://www.hard-fi.com |title=the official website for the new album - Killer Sounds |publisher=Hard-Fi |access-date=2011-08-17 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110809183952/http://hard-fi.com/ |archive-date=9 August 2011 |url-status=dead }} In 2007 ''Hard-Fi: Rockin' the City'' was nominated for "Best Podcast" at the [[Digital Music Awards]]. == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110809183952/http://hard-fi.com/ Official website] * [http://unofficial-hard-fi.proboards.com Unofficial Fans' Forum] {{Hard-Fi}} {{Authority control}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2020}} {{Use British English|date=August 2012}} [[Category:Hard-Fi| ]] [[Category:English rock music groups]] [[Category:Post-Britpop groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 2003]] [[Category:Musical groups disestablished in 2014]] [[Category:Musical groups reestablished in 2022]] [[Category:Atlantic Records artists]] [[Category:People from Staines-upon-Thames]]
